facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1953 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 61 of 1953. Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 16th day

facts.text: Appeal arises from High Court of Calcutta judgment and decree dated 16 May 1952 in Appeal from Original Decree No. 124 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Decree dated the 16th day of May, 1952 of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta in Appeal from Original Decree No. 124 of 1951 arising out

facts.text: High Court decree dated 25 May 1951 in Suit No. 3614 of 1950 in Ordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the decree dated the 25th day of May, 1951 of the High Court of Calcutta in its Ordinary Original Civil Jurisdiction in Suit No. 3614 of 1950.

facts.text: Suit filed by appellant against respondent to recover Rs. 1,25,962-2-0 with interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-This appeal with certificate from the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta arises out of the suit filed on the original side of the High Court by the appellant against the respondent to recover a sum of Rs. 1,25,962-2-0 with interest and costs

facts.text: Appellant entered into three contracts with respondent: two dated 8 August 1949 and one dated 17 August 1949.

anchor.surface_text: , 1073 The appellant entered into three contracts, two dated the 8th August 1949 and the third dated the 17th August 1949 with the respondent agreeing to purchase 1,80,000 bags

facts.text: Contracts for purchase of 1,80,000 bags B twills at Rs. 134/4/- per 100 bags, 1,80,000 at Rs. 135/4/-, 90,000 at Rs. 138/- for Oct, Nov, Dec 1949 deliveries in equal monthly instalments.

anchor.surface_text: of B twills at the price of Rs. 134/4/- per 100 bags, 1,80,000 bags at the rate of Rs. 135/4/- per 100 bags and 90,000 bags at the rate of Rs. 138/- per 100 bags respectively for October, November and December 1949 deliveries in equal monthly instalments

facts.text: In September 1949, respondent expressed inability to deliver goods and requested settlement by selling back at Rs. 161-8-0 per 100 bags.

anchor.surface_text: on terms and conditions contained in the relative contract forms of the Indian Jute Mills Association. In September 1949 the respondent expressed its inability to deliver the goods under the said contracts and requested the appellant to settle the same by selling back the goods under the said contracts to the respondent at the price of Rs. 161-8-0 per 100 bags.

facts.text: Three settlement contracts entered on 28 September 1949 at Rs. 161-8-0 per 100 bags on IJMA terms.

anchor.surface_text: Three settlement contracts were accordingly entered into between the parties on the 28th September 1949 whereby the appellant agreed to sell the goods under the original contracts to the respondent at the rate of Rs. 161- 8-0 per 100 bags on the terms and conditions contained in the relative contract forms

facts.text: Appellant submitted bills aggregating Rs. 1,15,650 which respondent accepted but failed to pay despite demands.

anchor.surface_text: of the Indian Jute Mills Association. The appellant duly submitted to the respondent his bills for the amounts due at the foot of the said contracts aggregating to Rs. 1,15,650 which the respondent accepted but failed and neglected to pay in spite of repeated demands of the appellant.

facts.text: Respondent contended settlement contracts illegal under West Bengal Jute Goods Future Ordinance, 1949; does not deal in actual delivery, no godown.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed its written statement contesting the appellants claim on the main ground that the three settlement contracts above-mentioned were illegal and prohibited by the West Bengal Jute Goods Future Ordinance, 1949. The respondent contended that it never dealt in the sale and or purchase of jute goods involving actual delivery of possession thereof, nor did it possess or have control over any godown

facts.text: Trial Court decreed appellant's claim, negatived respondent's contention.

anchor.surface_text: and other means or equipments necessary for the storage and supply of jute goods and that therefore the said settlement contracts were void and not binding upon it and that the appellant was not entitled to any relief as prayed. The Trial Court negatived the contention of the respon- 1074 dent and decreed the appellants -claim.

facts.text: High Court Appeal Court held settlement contracts void as forward basis by non-habitual dealer, only right to settle at last closing rate Rs. 146/14/-, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Appeal Court however came to the conclusion that the said settlement contracts were contracts relating to the purchase of jute goods made on a forward basis by the respondent not being a person who habitually dealt in the sale or purchase of jute goods involving the actual delivery of possession thereof and were therefore void and unenforceable.

facts.text: West Bengal Jute Goods Future Ordinance, 1949 came into force on 22 September 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Ordinance came into force on. the 22nd September 1949.

facts.text: Notification No. 4665 Com dated 23 September 1949 prohibited jute goods futures contracts from publication date.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the power conferred under section 3 (1) of the Ordinance the Government of West Bengal issued a notification, being notification No. 4665 Com. dated the 23rd September 1949 prohibiting the making of contracts relating to jute goods futures on and from the date of publication

facts.text: Notifications published in Calcutta Gazette on 23 September 1949.

anchor.surface_text: These notifications were published in the 1076 Calcutta Gazette on the same day, the 23rd September 1949.

facts.text: It is common ground that contracts did not provide for payment or receipt of margin.

anchor.surface_text: It was common ground that the contracts did not provide for the payment or receipt of margin.

facts.text: It is common ground that respondent did not possess or have control over godown or storage equipment.

anchor.surface_text: It was also common ground that the respondent did not possess or have control over a godown and other means and equipments necessary for the storage and supply of jute goods.

facts.text: In Calcutta jute trade, mills delivery orders issued against cash payment, pass by endorsement, represent goods.

anchor.surface_text: As a matter of fact on the evidence the learned Trial Judge held that in the Calcutta jute trade mills delivery orders are ordinarily issued by the mills against cash payment and pass from hand to hand by endorse- ment and are used in the ordinary course of business authorising the endorsee to receive the goods

facts.text: Chain contracts: mills to A, A to B, B to defendant (respondent), defendant to plaintiff (appellant), plaintiff to C, C to shipper.

anchor.surface_text: the Appeal Court accepted this position and further found that in the instant case the mills who held the goods sold them to A, A to B, B to the defendant to the plaintiff to C and C to the shipper. This is what is known as a chain contract.

facts.text: Each successive buyer paid full price in cash to immediate seller against endorsement of delivery order.

anchor.surface_text: the evidence on record being that each of the successive buyers paid to his immediate seller the full price of the goods represented by the delivery order in cash against the endorsement of the relative delivery order in his favour by the seller.

facts.text: Supreme Court held settlement contracts not void, reversed Appeal Court, accepted Trial Court view.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge was in our opinion correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent contention that Ordinance ultra vires was negatived by Appeal Court and not seriously pressed.

anchor.surface_text: A further contention which was raised by the respondent, viz. that the Ordinance was ultra vires was negatived by the Court. But in view of its finding on the main issue the Appeal Court dismissed the appellants suit with costs.

facts.text: Last closing rate in notified market was Rs. 146/14/- per 100 bags.

anchor.surface_text: The only right which the appellant had against the respondent was to have the said original contracts settled on the basis of the last closing rate in a notified market which was Rs. 146/14/- per 100 bags.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by BHAGWATI J. on 3 December 1954.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. December 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.-

concepts.unlisted_label: West Bengal Jute Goods Future Ordinance, 1949
concepts.unlisted_description: Ordinance regulating and prohibiting jute goods futures contracts in West Bengal

anchor.surface_text: Section 2. In this Ordinance,- unless there is anything repugnant in the subject or context- Contract relating to jute goods futures means a contract relating to the sale or purchase of jute goods made on a forward basis-  a providing for the payment or receipt, as the case may be, of margin in such manner and on such dates as may be specified in the contract, or  b  by or with any person not being a person who, habitually deals in the sale or purchase of jute goods involving the actual delivery of possession thereof, or possesses, or has control over, a godown and other means and equipments necessary for the storage and supply of jute goods

concepts.interpretation: Settlement contracts do not fall under this definition as no margin payment/receipt and respondent habitually deals involving actual delivery despite no godown.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 2, West Bengal Jute Goods Future Ordinance, 1949
concepts.unlisted_description: Defines 'Contract relating to jute goods futures'

anchor.surface_text: 3.  1  The Provincial Government may, from time to time, if it so thinks fit, by notification in the Official Gazette prohibit the making of contracts, relating to jute goods futures and may, by like notification, withdraw such prohibition 1075 When the making of contracts relating to jute goods futures is prohibited by a notification under sub-section  1 ,-  a no person shall make any such contract or pay or receive any margin except, in the case of any such contract made prior to the date of the notification, to the extent to which the payment or receipt, as the case may be, of margin is allowable on the basis of the last closing rate in a notified market  c notwithstanding anything contained in any other law for the time being in force,- every such contract made, and every claim in respect of margin, in contravention of the provisions of clause  a , shall be void and unenforceable, and every such contract made prior to the date of publication of the notification shall be varied and settled on the basis of the last closing rate in a notified market.

concepts.interpretation: Contracts made after prohibition are void if they are futures contracts; applied to hold settlement contracts enforceable.

holdings.text: The settlement contracts mentioned above could be called contracts between the appellant and the respondent involving the actual delivery of possession of the goods and are therefore not void under the Ordinance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No margin provision; respondent habitually deals in sales/purchases involving actual delivery via chain contracts, delivery orders/mates receipts representing goods passed against full cash payment; ultimate physical delivery translates constructive delivery along chain; Trial Court correct, Appeal Court erred on facts (full payments) and narrow 'actual delivery' view.

holdings.text: 'Actual delivery of possession' includes symbolical as well as constructive delivery, as contrasted with mere dealings in differences.

anchor.surface_text: Delivery has been defined in section 2 (2 ) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act as meaning voluntary transfer of possession from one person to another and if nothing more was said delivery would not only include actual delivery but also symbolic or constructive delivery within the meaning of the term.

holdings.reasoning_summary: SOGA s.2(2) defines delivery as voluntary transfer including symbolic/constructive; 'actual' distinguishes from difference settlements, not excluding constructive; business reality of jute trade chains makes narrow physical delivery impossible; mischief rule targets speculators avoiding delivery.

holdings.text: The word 'involving' means 'resulting in'; condition satisfied if chain contracts result in actual delivery of possession in ultimate analysis.

anchor.surface_text: The word involving in the context means resulting in and this condition would be satisfied if the chain contracts as entered into in the market resulted in actual delivery of possession of goods in the ultimate analysis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constructive delivery by documents (delivery orders/mates receipts) against cash passes possession along chain; culminates in physical delivery by mills to shipper, implementing all contracts eo instanti.

holdings.text: The Ordinance is not ultra vires; Provincial Legislature competent under Head 27 List II Seventh Schedule Government of India Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirms Appeal Court's holding; covers trade/commerce within province, markets/fairs; contention not seriously pressed.

holdings.text: The learned Trial Judge was correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Trial Judge was in our opinion correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Trial Court's findings on chain contracts, full cash payments, delivery orders representing goods; rejects Appeal Court's erroneous assumptions and narrow construction.

anchor.surface_text: Nippon Yusen Kaisha v. Ramjiban 1  in regard to the standard form of the Indian Jute Mills Association companytract- This is a form under which the entire export business in gunnies in Calcutta is company

precedents.cited_proposition: Standard form of the Indian Jute Mills Association contract under which the entire export business in gunnies in Calcutta is conducted; property prima facie passes when goods are appropriated by delivery alongside in implement of the contracts.
precedents.cited_holding: This is a form under which the entire export business in gunnies in Calcutta is conducted In the present case the sale being free alongside, the property prima facie passes when the goods are appropriated by delivery alongside in implement of the companytracts.

edges.explanation: Holding that contracts involve actual delivery directly addresses the issue.

anchor.surface_text: The question that falls to be determined on these facts and circumstances is whether the settlement contracts mentioned above could be called contracts between the appellant and the respondent involving the actual delivery of possession of the goods.

The Appeal Court was therefore clearly in error when it put a narrow construction on the expression actual delivery of possession and held that the transactions were purely speculative and the parties in no event contemplated actual delivery of possession of the goods. The learned Trial Judge was in our opinion correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Delivery has been defined in section 2 (2 ) of the Indian Sale of Goods Act as meaning voluntary transfer of possession from one person to another and if nothing more was said delivery would not only include actual delivery but also symbolic or constructive delivery within the meaning of the term.

The Appeal Court was therefore clearly in error when it put a narrow construction on the expression actual delivery of possession and held that the transactions were purely speculative and the parties in no event contemplated actual delivery of possession of the goods. The learned Trial Judge was in our opinion correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The word involving in the context means resulting in and this condition would be satisfied if the chain contracts as entered into in the market resulted in actual delivery of possession of goods in the ultimate analysis.

The Appeal Court was therefore clearly in error when it put a narrow construction on the expression actual delivery of possession and held that the transactions were purely speculative and the parties in no event contemplated actual delivery of possession of the goods. The learned Trial Judge was in our opinion correct in his appreciation of the whole position on facts as well as in law and in negativing the contention of the respondent.
